qas.question: What phrase did Roger Williams first use?

answers.text: "[A] hedge or wall of separation between the garden of the church and the wilderness of the world"

qas.question: What colony was Roger Williams the founder of?
When was the book The Bloody Tenent of Persecution published?
Who used William's phrase as a description of the First Amendment and its restriction on the legislative branch?

plausible_answers.text: hedge or wall of separation between the garden of the church and the wilderness of the world

qas.question: What phrase did Roger Williams never use?
What colony did Roger Williams escape from?
When was the book The Bloody Tenent of Persecution burned?
Who used William's phrase as a description of the Third Amendment and its restriction on the legislative branch?

context: The phrase <a1_0>"[A] <b6_0>hedge or wall of separation between the garden of the church and the wilderness of the world<b6_0/>"<a1_0/> was first used by <a0_0>Baptist theologian<a0_0/> <b5_0>Roger Williams<b5_0/>, the founder of the colony of <a2_0><b7_0>Rhode Island<b7_0/><a2_0/>, in his <a3_0><b8_0>1644<b8_0/><a3_0/> book The Bloody Tenent of Persecution. The phrase was later used by <a4_0><b9_0>Thomas Jefferson<b9_0/><a4_0/> as a description of the First Amendment and its restriction on the legislative branch of the federal government, in an 1802 letter to the Danbury Baptists (a religious minority concerned about the dominant position of the Congregationalist church in Connecticut):
